column2: Down the long avenue that led from the house to the great entrance gate came the Little Colonel on her pony.
column3: Down the long avenue that led from the house to the great entrance gate came the Little Colonel on her pony.

column2: It was a sweet, white way that morning, filled with the breath of the locusts; white overhead where the giant trees locked branches to make an arch of bloom nearly a quarter of a mile in length, and white underneath where the fallen blossoms lay like scattered snowflakes along the path.
column3: It was a sweet, white way that morning, filled with the breath of the locusts; white overhead where the giant trees locked branches to make an arch of bloom nearly a quarter of a mile in length, and white underneath where the fallen blossoms lay like scattered snowflakes along the path.

column2: Everybody, in Lloydsboro Valley knew Locust.
column3: Everybody, in Lloydsboro Valley knew Locust.

column2: It is one of the prettiest places in all Kentucky, they were fond of saying, and every visitor to the Valley was taken past the great entrance gate to admire the long rows of stately old trees, and the great stone house at the end, whose pillars gleamed white through the Virginia creeper that nearly covered it.
column3: It is one of the prettiest places in all Kentucky, they were fond of saying, and every visitor to the Valley was taken past the great entrance gate to admire the long rows of stately old trees, and the great stone house at the end, whose pillars gleamed white through the Virginia creeper that nearly covered it.

column2: Everybody knew old Colonel Lloyd, too, the owner of the place.
column3: Everybody knew old Colonel Lloyd, too, the owner of the place.

column2: He also was often pointed out to the summer visitors.
column3: He also was often pointed out to the summer visitors.

column2: Some people called attention to him because he was an old Confederate soldier who had given his good right arm to the cause he loved, some because they thought he resembled Napoleon, and others because they had some amusing tale to tell of the eccentric things he had said or done.
column3: Some people called attention to him because he was an old Confederate soldier who had given his good right arm to the cause he loved, some because they thought he resembled Napoleon, and others because they had some amusing tale to tell of the eccentric things he had said or done.

column2: Nearly every one who pointed out the imposing figure, which was clad always in white duck or linen in the summer, and wrapped in a picturesque military cape in winter, added the remark: "And he is the Little Colonel's grandfather." To be the grandfather of such an attractive little bunch of mischief as Lloyd Sherman was when she first came to the Valley was a distinction of which any man might well be proud, and Colonel Lloyd _was_ proud of it.
column3: Nearly every one who pointed out the imposing figure, which was clad always in white duck or linen in the summer, and wrapped in a picturesque military cape in winter, added the remark: "And he is the Little Colonel's grandfather." column2: He was proud of the fact that she had inherited his lordly manner, his hot temper, and imperious ways.
column3: He was proud of the fact that she had inherited his lordly manner, his hot temper, and imperious ways.

column2: It pleased him that people had given her his title of Colonel on account of the resemblance to himself.
column3: It pleased him that people had given her his title of Colonel on account of the resemblance to himself.

column2: She had outgrown it somewhat since she had first been nicknamed the Little Colonel.
column3: She had outgrown it somewhat since she had first been nicknamed the Little Colonel.

column2: Then she was only a spoiled baby of five; but now his pride in her was even greater, since she had grown into a womanly little maid of eleven.
column3: Then she was only a spoiled baby of five; but now his pride in her was even greater, since she had grown into a womanly little maid of eleven.

column2: He was proud of her delicate, flower-like beauty, of her dainty ways, and all her little schoolgirl accomplishments.
column3: He was proud of her delicate, flower like beauty, of her dainty ways, and all her little schoolgirl accomplishments.

column2: She is like those who have gone before, he used to say to himself sometimes, pacing slowly back and forth under the locusts; and the bloom-tipped branches above would nod to each other as if they understood.
column3: She is like those who have gone before, he used to say to himself sometimes, pacing slowly back and forth under the locusts; and the bloom tipped branches above would nod to each other as if they understood.

column3: Mother is her godmothah.

column2: That's why she is named Elizabeth Lloyd.
column3: That's why she is named Elizabeth Lloyd.

column2: Mrs. Lewis was an old school friend of mothah's, too, and she wants Joyce and Elizabeth and me to be as deah friends as she and Emily Ware and Joyce Lewis were, she says.
column3: mrs Lewis was an old school friend of mothah's, too, and she wants Joyce and Elizabeth and me to be as d e a h friends as she and Emily Ware and Joyce Lewis were, she says.

column2: That's why she invited them."

column2: And you don't know anything about this one? questioned Rob.
column3: And you don't know anything about this one? questioned Rob.

column2: Not a thing.	Not a thing.

column2: I shouldn't be su'prised if she's mighty countrified, for the farm is several miles from a railroad, and the people she lives with don't think of anything but work, yeah in and yeah out."
column3: I shouldn't be su'prised if she's mighty countrified, for the farm is several miles from a railroad, and the people she lives with don't think of anything but work, yeah in and yeah out."

column2: They had reached the post-office by this time, and Rob held out his hand for the letters.
column3: They had reached the post office by this time, and Rob held out his hand for the letters.

column2: I'll put them in for you, he said.
column3: I'll put them in for you, he said.

column2: Then, dropping them into the box, one by one, he repeated the rhyme:
column3: Then, dropping them into the box, one by one, he repeated the rhyme:

column2: One flew east and one flew west. And one flew into the cuckoo's nest.
column3: One flew east and one flew west. And one flew into the cuckoo's nest.

column2: Lloyd added, quickly:
column3: Lloyd added, quickly:

column2: Eugenia, Joyce, or Elizabeth, Which of the three shall we like best?
column3: Eugenia, Joyce, or Elizabeth, Which of the three shall we like best?

column2: Joyce, said Rob, promptly.
column3: Joyce, said Rob, promptly.

column2: I think so, too, agreed the Little Colonel, stooping to fasten the locust blossoms more securely behind the pony's ears.
column3: I think so, too, agreed the Little Colonel, stooping to fasten the locust blossoms more securely behind the pony's ears.

column2: Well, the invitations are off now.	Well, the invitations are off now.

column2: Come on, Tarbaby, and see if you can't beat Bobby Moore's old gray hawse so bad it will be ashamed to evah race again."
column3: Come on, Tarbaby, and see if you can't beat Bobby Moore's old gray hawse so bad it will be ashamed to evah race again."

column2: With that the little black pony was off like an arrow toward Locust, with the big gray horse thundering hard at its heels.
column3: With that the little black pony was off like an arrow toward Locust, with the big gray horse thundering hard at its heels.

column2: The dust flew, dogs barked, and chickens ran squawking across the road out of the way.
column3: The dust flew, dogs barked, and chickens ran squawking across the road out of the way.

column2: Heads were thrust out of the windows as the two vanished up the dusty pike, and an old graybeard loafing in front of the corner grocery gave an amused chuckle.
column3: Heads were thrust out of the windows as the two vanished up the dusty pike, and an old graybeard loafing in front of the corner grocery gave an amused chuckle.

column2: Beats all how them two do get over the ground, he said.
column3: Beats all how them two do get over the ground, he said.

column2: They ride like Tarn O'Shanter, and I'll bet a quarter there's nothing on earth that either of 'em are afraid of.
column3: They ride like Tarn O'Shanter, and I'll bet a quarter there's nothing on earth that either of 'em are afraid of.

column2: A little while later the three white envelopes were jogging sociably along, side by side in a mail-bag, on their way to Louisville.
column3: A little while later the three white envelopes were jogging sociably along, side by side in a mail bag, on their way to Louisville.

column2: But their course did not lie together long.
column3: But their course did not lie together long.

column2: In the city post-office they were separated, and sent on their different ways, like three white carrier-pigeons, to bid the guests make ready for the Little Colonel's house party.
column3: In the city post office they were separated, and sent on their different ways, like three white carrier pigeons, to bid the guests make ready for the Little Colonel's house party.
